As far as the English language Super Robot Wars games go (Alpha Gaiden, J, V, X, T and 30) it has the best story with clear themes and interesting development of characters. Most series feel like their story is important to the overall plot of the game (Witch from Mercury feels stubby for only having the first season included) and it makes the game more fun to see how the characters from different shows and their plots interweave and change from the original.

Gameplay's the usual Super Robot Wars fun gameplay, I played on Expert difficulty which provided a solid challenge. Towards the end of the game objective conditions start being introduced which work as a nice way to up the difficulty even if you've been Front grinding for credits and MxP. Music's great as usual, the new character designs are enjoyable. I'd say the mecha designs for the protagonist units are nicer than the OG antagonist units, but the music they come with is great nonetheless.

Nitpicks I'd have are mostly related to the new engine they've moved onto after 25? years of frankensteining on top of the Alpha engine; the unit screen isn't anywhere near as thorough or nice as it used to be, opting for a grid system with a filter option. I'm thinking primarily PS2/PS3 era SRW games you'd get a long list and you could sort and filter by *many* criteria like score, EN, terrain adaptability, strongest attack, if they can support attack or defend, do they use a shield, have a barrier, etc. The menus for buying and upgrading skills and parts is also clunky and hard to get through to find what you want quickly, similarly working on a scroll and filter system that resets its position every time you leave its window. This can make distributing your acquired skill parts very tedious in conjunction with how barebones the search menu is for your units and pilots.

Great Super Robot Wars game, I'd recommend to anyone interested in turn-based strategy JRPGs and hopefully by the next entry they've become more comfortable with the new engine they've moved onto and improve on the QOL menu stuff. I also expect the combat animations to keep improving and for them to be more comfortable, you could see in the attacks for the OG units and a handful of others like the Wing Gundam Zero that they can put out beautiful and awesome-looking attack animations.
This game is a blast! hoping for a remaster and release on Steam for the Z trilogy and the VTX trilogy.

Combat isn't much different from previous installments, but that's feels like more of a "don't try to fix what isn't broken" situation than anything.

The only thing I wish was a little more like 30, the most recent other one I've played, is the soundtrack. This one has more instrument only covers, as opposed to 30 where they had singers and the original songs with lyrics in most cases.

Probably one of my favorite english-speaking entries in the series (discounting fan trads, but that's another discussion entirely).

It builds on 30's structure and strengths, with a return of the free-select mission structure and an attempt at non-linear storytelling. Where it succeeds is that missions now focus on multiple series in parallel, and always feature mid battle events changing up the situation and the narrative, so it's a much more engaging experience both story and play wise.

The game's biggest strength is its writing and how it weaves all the crossovers together in a single, consistent world without relying on the parallel universe crutch from 30. Animations are still a bit of a mixed bag but still mostly on the very good end of the scale, with a much better use of 3D models.

The new engine the game is built on does mean a ton of decade-old muscle memory is now invalid when UI and UX are concerned (no more quick movement with R1+stick or quicksave with square/X) and there are improvements to be made still, but it's an intriguing development and I look forward to their next iteration on this new foundation.

Overall: if you've played SRW before, it's one of the better entries, not reaching the heights of the series japanese-only best but definitely memorable in its own right, with excellent OG units and music, cool story and animations, a surprising-yet-it-works cast, and plenty of small UI changes that make gameplay extremely fluid and stop relying on the old quicksave/quickload shenanigans.

If you haven't played SRW before... there isn't a better time than now, so if you're interested, get in the robot!

Super Robot Wars Y is an Incredible improvement over Super Robot Wars 30 (a low point in the franchise, if you are not familiar with it). Significant mechanical overhauls, better writing, more varied objectives and terrain usage, and really bolting down a lot of the mechanics added over the past few entries make the game much less of a stomp in favor of the player and much more of a, you know, game. All this said; there is room for improvement.

Let me start off by saying the plot is incredible and I love it. Super Robot Wars has always been about the plot, and Y is a return to form in a big way. A lot of series interconnectivity, and even better treatment of DLC characters puts it leagues ahead. My one minor complaint is that it is sort've a retread of the super robot wars 30 story, but I can respect it as essentially a "second attempt" at that plot.

Mechanically, not much has changed, but many of the auxilary systems (skill tree, assists, ExC, etc) have been remodeled and tightened up. No more ExC (so no more zealing your best unit across the map to kill every enemy on turn one), skill tree is much larger and upgrades are much more marginal, and assist crew entries are... pretty much the same, but they were never too bad. Difficulty remains fairly low, even on expert (I beat the entire game on expert, first run, putting no special effort in and only had to stop and think a couple of times; I am Not an SRPG Pro, and this is not a compliment). Difficulty is concentrated in the early game and the very late game, and if you're good at scaling your units well (doesn't take a particularly larg eamount of effort, tbh), the late game probably won't be so bad. Some minor difficulty spikes early on in new chapters, and in general it seems like this problem was, at least partially, a complication of the new (circa SRW 30) mission system, so I do have some sympathy. All this said; still absolutely massively better then SRW 30, which I nearly fell asleep playing several times. No joke.

An excellent step up all in all! I dunno if I'd reccomend it to people that aren't big on giant robots, and I don't need to sell it to people already playing super robot wars games, but it's certainly much better then super robot wars 30. Hope to see more improvements in later entries! The game doesn't need to be absurdly difficult, but I would like to have to think about how I'm playing more then like, 20% of the game. SRW Y is the best game the franchise has produced since the PS2 era, and I don't think it's particularly close. I say this as someone who thought SRW 30 was a disappointment to the point that I didn't preorder Y or even pay attention to any of the trailers or other pre-release media. I thought that the series list had too many retreads from 30 that would clog up my roster with units I didn't want to use. If you're wary of getting Y because of this same worry, let me reassure you: every single show in Y's roster more than pulls its weight, even (and in some cases [i]especially[/i]) the ones that reuse a bunch of units/animations/etc from 30.

The core appeal of SRW as a series has always been the crossover aspect - your favorite characters and robots from your favorite shows fighting and interacting with each other. Every game in the series does tons of crossover stuff - in fact, that's basically the entire point - but Y does it as well as any of them, if not better, and that's because of the writing. In an average SRW game, any given stage will usually primarily follow the plot of one particular show. Your whole team is there, of course, but they're mostly commenting from the sidelines and providing support to that stage's main characters. SRW Y stands out to me because the character dynamics and plotlines are constantly intertwined in fun ways that I don't expect. And if you track these dynamics and deploy people at appropriate points, you get bits of bonus dialogue. 

The writing isn't the only reason the game is such a success in my view. The core gameplay has also taken a step forward, most notably by having actual well-tuned difficulty settings. You can still effortlessly stomp the enemies if that's what you want, but the higher settings actually provide a good challenge now. The ExC and Supporter systems from the past few games have sort of been combined and replaced with a new Assist Link system which is more tactically interesting and rewarding. QOL is better than ever, most notably because you can finally save in battle (using actual save slots, not just a single suspend slot) and you can load a save in battle without needing to reset to the title screen. 

The game isn't flawless of course. The number one issue is that variety in enemy mechs is somewhat lacking - this is a persistent problem that the series has been facing for a long time. Some factions are worse offenders than others. The Custom BGM feature is somewhat poorly implemented in comparison to past games (basically, you can no longer adjust the volume of an individual track). The UI is a bit clunky in some ways. All of these are minor issues in the grand scheme of things, and some of them might even be able to be patched out.

This game is fun. I just cleared it for the first time as a SRW veteran.

Pros 
- A good mix of classic and newer mecha shows. The visuals on the OG mech and Gundam Wing are very impressive particularly, keep it up!

- The story is more cohesive than SRW 30 which had a similar idea with branching missions.

- Great to have clear conditions to unlock the side missions, a really nice touch.

- The new skills and seishin feel great. Especially the addition of gunfight/infight reminds me of the good old days of the SRW OG series allowing your ranged units to often outrange bosses and melee to counterattack from most ranges while moving very far.

- The challenge maps are pretty fun and have good variety. Even as a longtime player I had a good chuckle or two at what they expected of us while not being a complete pushover.

- The assist system is more balanced on average compared to the more recent EXC which made it incredibly easy to finish a map in 1-2 turns and at least this way you need specific setups to chain assists infinitely.

- The adjusted difficulties levels appear to suit every range of player. Even those I've talked to who consider the modern games extremely easy said that they were impressed at how the game felt to them now, from  the adjustments I mentioned earlier and also more terrain to make defensive plays worth it instead just throwing your units at the enemy and abusing the EXC system.

Neutral
- The change to PP is a massive one and it does consolidate resources more which's good (allowing weak mechs/pilots to become good provided you have enough funds rather than relying on them to regularly fight). This does however have the downside of making building a strong unit easier in the longterm but would require much grinding to get a perfect squad.

- Following on from that i have mixed feelings about the shop. It's cool that by lategame you can buy amazing items however I kind of wish they were limited, because with enough funds it's very easy to give these to all your best units and makes some of the trials feel less interesting as they don't give good items by comparison.

-Speeding through assist animations feels a bit weird. It would be nice to turn the animation off or simply skip through.

Cons
- The odd missing audio queue, which seems to happen sometimes when you speed through mech abilities with an animation.

- It sounds strange to say but before the DLC is available there's quite a lack of super units, meanwhile we are swimming in real robots. Not a giant problem personally but I can imagine some would be put off by this.

- Pre-order exclusive content, (good free OG units in this case) just feel like bad practice. If someone wanted to wait for a sale, they shouldn't be punished by being restricted from fun units.

- The new UI takes some getting used to. It does have good information especially on the main map but I feel like it took much longer overall to navigate and setup multiple units at once whereas in previous games this was better streamlined e.g. Activating the drive seishin on multiple characters I can search>drive then gives a list of characters but afaik It wouldn't allow me to select those characters kind of defeating the point of searching for them in the first place.

tl;dr A great addition to the Super Robot Wars series that has something for everyone and improves on almost every aspect of the more recent game, SRW 30. If you like mecha or strategy RPG's this should be a good time. Bless ya

用了90小时全成就了这个游戏，我给这游戏的评价：7分，不能再多了。我简短说一下

画面上跟X, V, T, 30没有区别，所以别期待什么画面上的飞跃。不仅没有进步，前几关时还有一个Z高达的敌人，那个敌人仿佛是从上世代的机战弄过来的，贴图都是糊的，给我一个很差的第一印象。
乳摇完全消失，期待这个的玩家要失望了。

游戏性上跟以前的作品基本一样，只要你玩一部机战，你就能知道其他机战玩起来什么样。虽然本作加入了一个辅助成员的系统，其实你一玩就明白了，跟前作的系统很像。
本作把关卡改成了主线任务和支线任务，其实放在以前的机战里，这都是主线任务。这么一改的话，大大减少了速通游戏的时间。我第一周目通关，主线+所有支线+所有挑战，74小时通关。第二周目通关，只打主线，16小时。

游戏的难度似乎提高了，在游戏后期，普通难度下，小兵打全改的v高达竟然都有40-50%的命中率。在最高难度下，小兵打无改的沙扎比，竟然是100%命中率，而且2枪就死。
敌人的数量也大大增加了，尤其是后期关卡，有一关直接80多架敌方机体，还有一关有无限增援。挺爽的，机战无双。

剧情上倒是有大大的改进，这次各个作品的世界观融合的很好，不像前作生硬的把其他作品的机体“时空转移”进来，在本作中所有作品都存在于这个世界里，所以一切事情发生的比较自然。
但似乎因为这种对世界观融合的需求，参战作品很少，这可能是机体最少的一作。而且有些参展新作品挺无聊的，比如哥斯拉奇异点，喷射杰特是相当无聊的机体。

说说不满意的地方：
1. 游戏男女主角，但其实这俩主角的机体都是一样的，升级后的机体也是一样的，唯一的区别就是机体颜色不一样，还有升级最终必杀技不一样。 男女主角没有专属的任务，也没有专属的行为模式和故事。你玩过一个主角的故事，你就知道另一个主角的故事什么样了。
而且玩这游戏90%的人都会选女主角，女主角在设定上也更加讨好。以后若是不想做不同主角的专属任务和机体的话，还是取消双主角的设定算了。(回想过去的机战，不同的主角机体不一样，任务不一样，性格也不一样，啧啧啧)

2. 机体少不说，有些该有机体的没有，比如Hi-v高达就没有，全装甲百式都有了，为什么没有夜莺。而长得一模一样的Macross战斗机倒是一下给了5个。Seed的机体也没有流星系统

3. 多蒙的神高达没有超级霸王电影弹. 

4.高达水星的魔女说是剧情包含了第一季，但实际上第一季就最后几集的剧情完全没出现。来自于地球的高达完全没有。

5. 最终boss缺乏以往boss的魄力。以前的boss要么是神，要么是宇宙的创造者什么的。然后战斗都是在异空间进行的。这次的boss感觉就是个很厉害的人罢了。我一直都不敢相信这个是真正的boss，直到我打通游戏才不得不接受这个设定。

说了这么多总结一下就是，这游戏7分不能再高。有好的地方，有坏的地方，但是因为是机战，所以爱玩的人依然会玩。不看机器人动画的人甚至无法理解这游戏的吸引力在哪。

The negatives: Really its mostly just the UI being both uglier than the rest of the series and less functional. In a vacuum it's far from the worst I've seen in a strategy RPG but any longtime series veteran will immediately notice issues like Spirit Search being less functional or the fast forward feature outside of battles needing to reset your button inputs a lot. Also of all the new shows implemented, Witch from Mercury is the one that feels the most forced/awkwardly implemented[at least in scenes involving the show's own plot, suletta and friends are cute and enjoyable when crossing over into other series'].

The positives: This is the most fleshed out strategy RPG the series has had since Moon Dwellers. If you thought 30 was too easy/boring, this game refreshed all the basic mechanics from the ground up while still being recognizably SRW. Hard/Expert mode are a ton of fun for me, as someone who's been playing these games since the PS1 entries. Tons of units with distinct abilities and traits, difficult enough to make you have to take fights seriously without degrading into an opaque puzzle game, and with lots of fun character interactions in the way you can only get in SRW. The scenario select system from 30 returns but in a form more comparable to Impact/MX, where the game is split up into chapters with their own individual flowcharts. Helps the pace of the story tremendously and is easier to parse on the gameplay side of things too. Speaking of, the story itself has an interesting twist to it compared to other entries[there is no more Earth Federation, your team is an independent city state on top of a giant 3km long ship] that changes a bunch of stuff you'd take for granted in any other entry of the series. Overall a big step in the right direction and hopefully a sign of more good things to come, I hope they at least do some patches to improve the UI usability issues and maybe get a nicer looking UI in mind for the next game.

Super Robot Wars Y is an Incredible improvement over Super Robot Wars 30 (a low point in the franchise, if you are not familiar with it). Mechanically, not much has changed, but many of the auxilary systems (skill tree, assists, ExC, etc) have been remodeled and tightened up. No more ExC (so no more zealing your best unit across the map to kill every enemy on turn one), skill tree is much larger and upgrades are much more marginal, and assist crew entries are... pretty much the same, but they were never too bad. Difficulty remains fairly low, even on expert (I beat the entire game on expert, first run, putting no special effort in and only had to stop and think a couple of times; I am Not an SRPG Pro, and this is not a compliment). Difficulty is concentrated in the early game and the very late game, and if you're good at scaling your units well (doesn't take a particularly larg eamount of effort, tbh), the late game probably won't be so bad. Some minor difficulty spikes early on in new chapters, and in general it seems like this problem was, at least partially, a complication of the new (circa SRW 30) mission system, so I do have some sympathy. All this said; still absolutely massively better then SRW 30, which I nearly fell asleep playing several times. No joke.

Pros:

-Out of the modern SRW games(V, X, T, 30 and Y) SRW Y probably has one of the stronger narratives.

-This is probably the most balanced SRW out of the modern SRW games, with almost every unit and pilot having a use, the system being refined even further than the previous installments, and the assists system improving to a very meaningful degree that basically allows for certain combination of assists to fit your playstyle. 

Cons:

-The mission select system, while it is improved over the mission select system in SRW 30, it still makes the game needlessly longer than needed, and adds a lot of filler content through side missions and front missions. While an argument can be made that you do not have to do these side missions and front missions. You will be penalized for abandoning them by either missing units, finding yourself lacking funds, and sometimes side missions actually end up being as important as main missions to the narrative. SRW for the most part has had a linear story with occasional branching paths, which would encourage more than one playthrough to see everything you missed the first time around, I hope we go back to that for the future installments.

-The robot models and animations: specifically the newer ones mostly either made for 30 or Y. It is clear that most of these are severely lacking in quality when compared to the ones that were port from V, X and T. A lot of the ones from V are actually from SRW Z3 an even older game. I hope the team goes back to making beautiful animations; like the ones in SRW Z1 and SRW Z2. While some attack animations for the newer robots certainlly look cool due to effects and excellent direction(The OG protagonists for example.) The model of their robot looks blocky and awkward, I am sure if it was animated differently the design would look a lot better. On the other hand other units like the ones from Macross Delta were absolutly the worst, especially when you compare them to attacks from the Macross Series from SRW Z2 and SRW Z3. The animation is by far something they need to improve on and I hope we will see something more impressive in the future releases.

-Lack of choices when it comes to OG Protagonists. Its true that we could choose between two heroes, but they essentially piloted the same robot, and aside from some stylistic and color differences, the only other thing that changed was the animation for one attack. This is very limited especially when compared to SRW Alpha 2 and SRW Alpha 3 where you had four choices of OG Protagonists, two of them would pilot Super Robot Types, while the other two would pilot Real Robot Types and all of these robot choices would be different. Still SRW Y is at least a slight improvement over SRW X, T, and 30 where you had one OG robot and only could choose between two pilots, but SRW V is superior to SRW Y here as it allowed you to choose to get a Super Type or a Real Type midgame.

-While I praised the narrative of SRW Y, it has to be said that taking the same story elements for the OG cast from SRW 30 and copying them to SRW Y, even with making enough changes, is something that I hope doesn't become a trend. There is no need to revisit the story of a young captain, obtaining a mysterious, massive battleship, and have the OG robot pilot vow to protect them. Yes it was done much better in SRW Y than in SRW 30, but that doesn't mean that seeing these same story elements again, after I have just seen them in SRW 30 was a good feeling, if anything it gave me pause and made me not have expectations for the plot, but thankfully the story was much, much better than SRW 30.

-Enemy variety is extremely lacking.

The majority of the rest are either recycled from VXT30 (which imo were largely bad to begin with) or new and just ugly. Instead of the pixel art of the older games or the gorgeous style of the OG games we get this ugly 3D-2D style that belongs in a G-Generation game and not SRW.

2. The story is awful. They take a promising start with a floating city-state and what that could do in a post-war world and squander it, and the only other high point is when they lean into the Getter Arc story, but that gets overtaken by the nonsensical Godzilla plot. At the risk of beating a dead horse, we used to get unique BGM overriding themes for EVERY MEMBER of the enemy faction. All memorable with a leitmotif that tied them all together. To the End of the Galaxy is instantly recognizable. Moon Knights is instantly recognizable.

It doesn't feel great.

I'll preface this by saying I've played almost every entry in the franchise save a few, mostly from the Masoukishin side of things. I started with SRW3 back when I was a kid and emulating it on ZSNES on my moms work computer after school and have been a superfan ever since. I own soundtracks, models, lots of random plastic crap and was one of the first people to upload footage of the franchise to youtube all the way back in 2008. (https://www.youtube.com/@FlamingGnats) - If you need proof.

All this is to show that I wanted the game to be great, like I do all of them. Unfortunately, after close to 110 hours I finished it more relieved at it being over than anything else.

In my opinion the franchise has been on a downward decline since the PS3 era (and arguably even further back in the PSP era), but the most recent entries have shown such a lack of passion that I'm convinced that their windfall in the form of the mobile game has removed any reason for them to care about the main entries outside of releasing them just to show the franchise is technically still alive. 

V was good enough but the setting did a lot of the heavy lifting.
X was middling but at least showed that that leaning too hard into magic focused series does not work.
T was aggressively mediocre.
30 was where it started to feel phoned in. Quantity over quality. The UI was atrocious, the mission select killed any cohesiveness to the story, and the originals were dull and uninspired.

Y somehow made me wish I was playing any of the previous 4 instead, even if I've already beaten them all twice before. What little good there is gets vastly overshadowed by the bad and the overall laziness of the game. Let's go into more detail.

1. 3-4 units have legitimately impressive animations that I suspect were all done by the one guy left on the team with any actual passion. The majority of the rest are either recycled from VXT30 (which imo were largely bad to begin with) or new and just ugly. Instead of the pixel art of the older games or the gorgeous style of the OG games we get this ugly 3D-2D style that belongs in a G-Generation game and not SRW.

2. The story is awful. They take a promising start with a floating city-state and what that could do in a post-war world and squander it, and the only other high point is when they lean into the Getter Arc story, but that gets overtaken by the nonsensical Godzilla plot. Every time I saw someone say Singular Point I ground my teeth. Godzilla itself only appears in 2 missions at the very end of the game, but you're subjected to paragraphs of technobabble from the anime series that is not interesting in the least.

The originals are boring, though the idea of ninja robots is novel even if it's already been done way better in the franchise already. Art between the characters varies wildly from decent to amateurish, and to the surprise of noone the enemy faction ends up being 90% AI enemies with very little interesting about them. Gone are the days of the original enemy factions being so cool you looked forward to facing them, or seeming like an actual enemy empire and not 50 guys and 5000 AI controlled bots. We'll never get another Balmar, Insalaum, CHIMERA, etc.

3. The music was unimpressive. Some of the choices they made for the series were bizarre and didn't sound good at all, and the original units got maybe one memorable track out of the bunch. At the risk of beating a dead horse, we used to get unique BGM overriding themes for EVERY MEMBER of the enemy faction. All memorable with a leitmotif that tied them all together. I doubt anyone could tell you which final boss theme is for each boss if you took all of them from VXT30Y, but Untrue Crystal is instantly recognizable. Chimera is instantly recognizable. To the End of the Galaxy is instantly recognizable. Moon Knights is instantly recognizable. 

4. The devs heard all the complaints about 30's abominable UI and went way too far in the other direction. It's too minimalist and has no personality, and they crammed portraits into a tiny window during battle for no good reason whatsoever.

5. FOMO DLC and DLC in general for these games is stupid. Want to play through the whole thing at launch? Nah, you gotta wait for the DLC that adds all the stuff they cut out and the REAL ending.

The game feels cheap, cheaper than 30 which already felt like a cash grab. You can tell they consider the single player games an afterthought because DD prints money for a fraction of the effort. They're relying on too many "weird" new series being thrown in that really just don't fit instead of pulling from the many older shows people would love to see return, or even newer actual mecha shows. Majestic Prince sucks.

Call me an elitist or behind the times but these games could be so much more. I'm not gonna say "don't buy it" because that won't change anything, if profits fell they'd just stop making single player games entirely and only focus on their gacha slop, plus I'd be a hypocrite. I plan to force myself through the game again once all the DLC is out. I feel like I have to. 

It didn't have to be this way, though. As a great man once asked: "How does it feel to live long enough to see all your favorite franchises go down in flames?" 

It doesn't feel great.
